importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the recent announcement of Daniel Naroditsky's death.
The year Daniel Naroditsky won the Under 12 world championship, marking the beginning of his early career as a child prodigy.
The year Daniel Naroditsky earned his bachelor's degree in history from Stanford University.
The date he won the U.S. National Blitz Championship, a key achievement in his later career.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Daniel Naroditsky rose from a child prodigy to a globally recognized chess grandmaster and educator, with his influence growing through streaming and live commentary.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29.
He was a child prodigy who won the Under 12 world championship in 2007.
He became a grandmaster at 18 and consistently ranked in the top 200 globally in traditional chess and in the top 25 in blitz chess.
Naroditsky was known for livestreaming chess games on YouTube and Twitch, helping to popularize the sport and make it accessible to a broad audience.
He earned a bachelor's degree in history from Stanford University in 2019.
He coached junior chess players in Charlotte, North Carolina, after college.
He was a close friend and competitor of Dutch grandmaster Benjamin Bok.
American grandmaster Hikaru Nakamura praised Naroditsky for his educational approach and passion for sharing the game.
The cause of death was not immediately known.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Daniel Naroditsky is the central figure of the article, whose death at 29 marks a significant loss in the chess world. He was a leading figure in popularizing chess through digital platforms and was widely respected among peers and fans.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, a prominent American chess grandmaster and child prodigy, died at the age of 29. Born in San Mateo County, California, he won the Under 12 world championship in 2007 and became a grandmaster at 18. He gained widespread recognition for his educational livestreams on YouTube and Twitch, where he shared live commentary and gameplay, helping to popularize chess among a global audience. Naroditsky earned a bachelor's degree in history from Stanford University in 2019 before moving to Charlotte, North Carolina, to coach junior players. He was celebrated not only for his competitive success in both traditional and blitz chess but also for his mentorship and passion for making chess accessible. Fellow grandmasters, including Benjamin Bok and Hikaru Nakamura, expressed deep personal and professional grief at his passing. The cause of death remains unknown.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
